newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks bound higher on soft payrolls report.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks bound higher on soft payrolls report.

text.p: Wall Street stocks raced to new record levels at Friday's midsession after a shockingly weak September payrolls report calmed inflation fears and triggered furious buying in the bond market.
The Dow industrials rose 37 points to 5970 after climbing as many as 50 points in late morning activity and the S&P 500 jumped eight points to top the 700 mark for the first time.
"From the market's perspective, the (payrolls) report seemed to validate the soft-landing school of thought," said Michael Metz, Oppenheimer & Co chief investment strategist.

The September employment data included an unexpected 40,000 decline in non-farm payrolls. Economists had expected non-farm payroll growth to slow in the month, but even so had called for about 166,000 jobs to be added.

Bonds surged on the figure, which confirmed a slowing of the economy and dispelled some of the worst fears about the near-term prospect of inflation. The benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury surged more than a full point, pushing the yield down to the psychologically key 6.75 level.
The stocks market's rally was less dramatic, and analysts noted the news was actually a mixed blessing for equities.
"You can't get away from the possibility that in a slowing economy, earnings will also slow," said Peggy Farley, chief executive at Amas Securities.
A weak earnings report at one Dow component -- Aluminum Co of America -- pulled the average well off its highs.
Alcoa, which was halted for trading ahead of release of its earnings, reported a third quarter profit of $0.39 per share after accounting for a $0.38 charge.
The earnings were well short of analysts' estimates and upon resuming trade, Alcoa slumped three points to 57-1/2, dragging the Dow industrials lower with it.

Concern about upcoming earnings has tended to undermine the stock market's ability to participate in bond market rallies the way it had earlier in the year and analysts said a severe slowing of the economy would only intensify worries.
"You're already seeing a dramatic slowdown in the rate of earnings growth," Metz said, "and I believe we're going to see more pressure on corporate profits in 1997."
The increasingly favorable interest rate environment was greeted quite enthusiastically in the rate-sensitive financial sector, which saw share prices surge.
Wells Fargo & Co soared 5-3/8 to 266-3/8, BankAmerica Corp jumped two points to 86-1/2, Bankers Trust New York Corp gained 1-3/4 to 81-5/8 and Morgan Stanley Group Inc climbed 1-3/8 to 51-1/2.
In individual issues Stratus Computer Inc jumped 2-3/4 to 22-1/2 after Salomon Brothers upgraded the shares to strong buy.
Raytheon Co tumbled 4-1/8 to 48-7/8 after warning its third quarter operating income would be about 15 percent lower than year-ago levels.
Redhook Ale slid 4-5/16 to 16-3/4 after Smith Barney downgraded the shares to neutral from outperform.
